Description:
Titre de circulation italien
Châssis n° ZFFAA17B000074429


- Magnifiquement préservée

- Carnets d’entretien, trousse à outils

- Combinaison de couleurs d’origine rarissime

- Historique italien connu

- Modèle avec écrou central (Monodado)

 

Cette Ferrari Testarossa, version "monodado" dotée des jantes à serrage central au lieu de celles à cinq goujons des versions ultérieures, a été vendue neuve le 14 octobre 1987 à Giorgio Zancanaro, qui l'a immatriculée VR804258. Domicilié à Vérone, Zancanaro était un chanteur d'opéra, baryton, qui se produisait sur des scènes telles que Covent Garden à Londres ou le Metropolitan Opera à New York.

En 1988, cette Testarossa a rejoint le collectionneur sicilien A. di Stefano, basé à Syracuse, qui l'a gardée jusqu'en 1999. Il l'a ensuite cédée au spécialiste Autoluce, à Modène, qui a son tour l'a vendue à une dame de Reggio Emilia. En 2004, cette Ferrari a été achetée, par l'intermédiaire d'un négociant de Modène, par un collectionneur de Forli qui l'a ensuite cédée à son actuel propriétaire.

 

Cette Ferrari Testarossa sort de l'ordinaire par sa rare combinaison de couleurs, peinture blanche et intérieur en cuir bleu. Une présentation rarissime qui n'est pas sans rappeler celle de la Testarossa de la série "Deux flics à Miami", livrée noire par l'usine mais repeinte en blanc pour montrer une allure plus exclusive. Remplaçant la Ferrari Daytona Spyder des deux premières saisons de la célèbre série, elle a fait sensation entre les mains de Don Johnson, alias James "Sonny" Crockett !

 

Cette voiture est aujourd'hui dans un superbe état de préservation, avec son impressionnante robe blanche et son intérieur d'origine, dans un bleu foncé de grande classe. Les beaux sièges baquets sont à peine patinés, l'habitacle est impeccable et le compartiment moteur d'une grande propreté permet d'admirer le magnifique 12-cylindres à plat 5L développant 390 ch. Cette Testarossa très exclusive est accompagnée de son carnet d'entretien qui atteste notamment de révisions effectuées par Motor Service, à Modène, en 1991 (10 000 km), 2000 (20 000 km), 2002 (30 000 km) et 2003 (40 000 km). Elle affiche aujourd'hui quelque 50 000 km. Une révision complète, avec remplacement de la courroie de distribution, a été effectuée en 2024, et l'on note la présence de la trousse à outils.

 

Il s'agit donc d'un exemplaire particulièrement désirable par son état, sa provenance et sa combinaison de couleur sans équivalent : la certitude de se distinguer de toutes les autres Testarossa !

 

 

 

Italian title

Chassis no. ZFFAA17B000074429

 

- Beautifully preserved

- Service books, tool kit

- Extremely rare original color combination

- Documented Italian history

- Model with central wheel nut (Monodado)

 

This Ferrari Testarossa, a “monodado” version with central wheel nuts rather than the later five-bolt versions, was sold new on 14th October 1987 to Giorgio Zancanaro, who registered it VR804258. Zancanaro was a baritone opera singer who lived in Verona and performed on stages such as Covent Garden in London and the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

In 1988, this Testarossa went to the Sicilian collector A. di Stefano, based in Syracuse, who kept it until 1999. He then sold it to the specialist Autoluce in Modena, who in turn sold it to a lady in Reggio Emilia. In 2004, this Ferrari was purchased through a Modena dealer by a collector from Forli, who sold it to its current owner.

 

This is a stand-out Ferrari Testarossa with a rare color combination of white paintwork and blue leather interior. A rare combination not unlike the Testarossa in the series “Miami Vice”, delivered in black from the factory but repainted white for a more exclusive look. It replaced the Ferrari Daytona Spyder in the first two seasons of the famous series, and caused a sensation in the hands of Don Johnson, alias James “Sonny” Crockett!

 

Today, this car is in superb condition, with its impressive white livery and original interior in classy dark blue. The handsome bucket seats have barely acquired a patina, the interior is impeccable, and the clean engine compartment lets you admire the magnificent 390 hp 5-litre 12-cylinder flat engine. This exclusive Testarossa comes with its service book, which includes servicing by Motor Service, Modena, in 1991 (10,000 km), 2000 (20,000 km), 2002 (30,000 km) and 2003 (40,000 km). The clock now shows some 50,000 km. It was fully serviced in 2024, including a replacement the timing belt, and we note the presence of the tool kit.

 

This is a particularly desirable example in terms of condition, provenance and unmatched colour combination: it will definitely stand out from all other Testarossas!



Photos © Francesco Regiani

Description:
Titre de circulation hollandais
Châssis n° 5217 Moteur n° 5217 Interne n°1750/62 E


- Restauration exceptionnelle, mécanique d'origine

- Utilisée avec parcimonie par des collectionneurs soigneux

- Modèle rare, considéré comme une des plus belles Ferrari jamais produites

- Inspectée par Ferrari Classiche ; certification (Red Book) en cours d’impression

 

Avec sa ligne d'une grande élégance signée Pininfarina, la Ferrari 250 GT Lusso ("luxe") est une des plus belles Ferrari jamais produites. Faisant partie de la grande famille des 250 GT, avec son excellent V12 de 3 litres, elle est à la fois sophistiquée et fiable. Sorte de version assagie de la très sportive 250 GT "châssis court", elle présente un aménagement exclusif qui lui est propre, avec ses gros compteurs au centre, et un luxe de finition qui en fait une Grand Tourisme de grande classe. De plus, elle est d'une grande rareté : la production s'est limitée à 351 exemplaires.

 

Selon le rapport du spécialiste Marcel Massini et le ‘Vehicle Production Data’ de Ferrari Classiche, cette 250 GT Lusso sort d'usine le 27 novembre 1963 et, le 4 décembre suivant, un certificat d'origine est établi par Ferrari. Elle est ensuite livrée neuve le 12 décembre 1963 au concessionnaire officiel Gastone Crepaldi Automobili, de Milan, en Italie, qui la vend le même jour à son premier propriétaire, Salvatore Consolo, de Milan, au prix de 5 750 000 lires. Elle est de couleur "Grigio Argento" (référence 18.940 M Italver), avec une sellerie "Pelle Rossa" (référence VM3171). Immatriculée le 9 janvier sous le numéro "MI 857920", elle fait l'objet d'une révision le 11 juin à l'usine Ferrari, alors que le compteur affiche 13 310 km. Le 23 juillet 1963, elle est vendue par l'intermédiaire de Dino Armando Pedrino à son deuxième propriétaire, Dario Ferrari, de Milan, pour 3 500 000 lires. L'année suivante, elle traverse l’Atlantique vers les États-Unis et, au début des années 70, entre les mains de John Levy, d'Arlington.

Entre cette époque et la fin des années 90, elle connait plusieurs propriétaires américains et, en 2002, elle est proposée à la vente dans une annonce publiée dans la Ferrari Market Letter par le spécialiste Mike Sheehan, où elle y est présentée noire avec sellerie noire.

En 2002, elle revient en Europe pour être vendue le 14 janvier 2003 au collectionneur allemand Karl-Gustav Diederichs, de Remsheid, par l'intermédiaire d'Uwe Meissner, de Modena Motorsport, établissement basé à Langenfeld, près de Düsseldorf.

Entre 2005 et 2009, elle est vue aux journées circuit organisées en juin au Nürburgring par Modena Motorsport et, en juillet 2006, Diederichs prend part au Tour Inter-Europa et au Concours d'Élégance à côté du Nürburgring.

 

En 2003, après son achat, notre Lusso fait l'objet d'une restauration complète par Modena Motorsport, comme en atteste une facture totalisant plus de 178 000 € de travaux. La mécanique est complètement refaite et, dans l'habitacle, toutes les pièces et garnitures usées ou abîmées sont restaurées ou remplacées. Les chromes sont vérifiés ou refaits et la carrosserie est repeinte de couleur rouge, "Rosso Pininfarina". D'autres factures de 2010 montrent que la voiture appartenait encore à cette époque à KH Diederichs, avant qu'il ne la cède peu après à un autre collectionneur allemand, Ilka Seekamp, de Brême. C'est lui qui, a à son tour l’a vendue en décembre 2020 au propriétaire actuel. Il la fait réviser en février 2021 (le compteur affichait 57 701 km), puis repeindre dans sa magnifique teinte actuelle « Grigio Fumo Metalizzato » (une facture de quelque 30 000 € en témoigne dans le dossier).

 

Cette splendide 250 GT Lusso se trouve aujourd’hui dans un état époustouflant, montrant la haute qualité de la restauration chez Modena Motorsport. Cette superbe Lusso est accompagnée de sa documentation historique est équipée de sa carrosserie et de sa mécanique d'origine. L’inspection et toutes les photographies pour la certification Ferrari Classiche ont été réalisées et, validées par l’usine. Ne reste plus qu’à attendre le fameux Red Book qui sera transmis à l’acheteur dès réception. Un essai sur route a été réalisé et nous a permis de prendre toute l’ampleur de la restauration. Son comportement routier est exemplaire, absorbant les défauts de la chaussée avec une parfaite assise, le moteur montant dans les tours de manière franche et agile. Utilisée avec parcimonie et affichant une authenticité indiscutable, il s'agit d'une magnifique représentante de cette Ferrari rare et recherchée, qui mêle luxe, élégance et sportivité dans un savant cocktail dont seule la marque au cheval cabré avait le secret.



Le service de certification Ferrari est revenu vers le vendeur cette semaine en demandant quatre modifications mineures pour obtenir le Red Book. Elles seront donc réalisées immédiatement après la vente, aux frais du vendeur, avant d'être livrée à l'acquéreur.

 



 

Dutch title

Chassis No 5217

Engine No 5217

Internal No 1750/62 E

 

- Exceptional restoration, Matching numbers

- Carefully driven by meticulous collectors

- Rare model, considered one of the most beautiful Ferrari ever produced

- Inspected by Ferrari Classiche, certification (Red Book) currently being printed

 

Elegantly designed by Pininfarina, the Ferrari 250 GT Lusso (“luxury”) is one of the most beautiful Ferrari cars ever made. Part of the great 250 GT family and powered by an excellent 3-litre V12 engine, it is both sophisticated and reliable. As a toned-down version of the very sporty 250 GT “short wheelbase”, it features its own unique layout with large gauges in the middle and a luxurious finish, making it a high-class Grand Tourer. Furthermore, this specific model is extremely rare and only 351 examples were produced.

According to the report by specialist Marcel Massini and Ferrari Classiche’s Vehicle Production Data, this 250 GT Lusso left the factory on the 27th November 1963 and on the 4th December, a certificate of authentication was issued by Ferrari. It was then delivered new on the 12th December 1963 to the official dealership Gastone Crepaldi Automobili in Milan (Italy), who sold it the same day to its first owner Salvatore Consolo from Milan for 5,570,000 lira. It was delivered in “Grigio Argento” colour (reference 18.940 M Italver), combined with “Pelle Rossa” upholstery (reference VM3171). Registered on the 9th January under the number “MI 857920”, it had a service carried out at the Ferrari factory on the 11th June when the mileage was displaying 13,310 km on the odometer.

On the 23rd July 1963, it was sold through Dino Armando Pedrino to its second owner, Dario Ferrari from Milan for 3,500,000 lira. The following year, it crossed the Atlantic to the United States and in the early 1970s, it was acquired by John Levy of Arlington.

Between then and the late 1990s, it had several American owners; in 2002, It was listed for sale in an advertisement published in the Ferrari Market Letter by specialist Mike Sheehan, where it was presented in black with black upholstery. It returned to Europe in 2002, where it was sold on the 14th January 2003 to a German collector called Karl-Gustav Diederichs of Remseid by the intermediate of Uwe Meissner of Modena Motorsport, based in Langenfeld near Dusseldorf.

Between 2005 and 2009, it was seen at track day events organised in the month of June by Modena Motorsport; and in July 2006, Diederichs took part in the Inter-Europa Tour and the Concours d’Elegance near the Nurburgring

.

Following its purchase in 2003, this particular Lusso had a full restoration carried out by Modena Motorsport, as evidenced by an invoice totalling more than €178,000. The engine had a complete rebuild and inside, all worn / damaged parts and trim were restored or replaced. The chrome was checked or redone; the bodywork was repainted in “rosso Pininfarina”. Other invoices from 2010 indicate that the car was still owned by KH Diederichs at that time, before selling shortly after to another German collector, Ilka Seekamp from Bremen. It was the latter who then sold it in December 2020 to the current owner. He had it serviced in February 2021 (mileage showing 57,701 km) and then repainted in its current stunning colour “Grigio Fumo Metalizzato” (evidenced by an invoice of around €30,000 included in the file).

 

This incredible 250 GT Lusso is today in stunning condition, reflecting the high quality of the restoration at Modena Motorsport. This superb Lusso is accompanied by its historical documentation and is fitted with its original bodywork and engine. The Inspection and all photographs for the Ferrari Classiche certification were carried out and validated by the factory. The famous Red Book is currently being printed and will be handed over to the buyer upon receipt. A test drive was carried out on the road and enabled us to fully appreciate the extent of the restoration. Its road handling is truly exemplary and absorbs road imperfections with great poise; as for the engine, it climbs through the revs with impressive smoothness and agility. Carefully driven and displaying an indisputable authenticity, this is a magnificent representative of a rare and highly sought-after Ferrari which is able to blend luxury, elegance, and sportiness in the unique way that only the Prancing Horse could deliver.



Ferrari's certification department returned to the seller this week, requesting four minor modifications to obtain the Red Book.

These will be carried out immediately after the sale, at the seller's costs, before delivery to the buyer.



Photos © Kevin Van Campenhout

Justification: The description provides detailed information about the Ferrari 250 GT Lusso, including its history, condition, and specifications. The text explicitly mentions the brand, chassis number, and various aspects of the car's condition and provenance.

Description:
Carte grise française
Châssis n° SAXXKFP328S680770


- Voiture extrêmement originale et ludique

- État très satisfaisant

- 6 000 € de révision mécanique en 2023

- Sans Réserve



Symbole des années 1960 et 1970, la Moke conçue par BMC sur une base de Mini n'a pas été retenue par l'armée britannique à qui elle était destinée, et s'est transformée en voiture en vogue autant dans le "Swinging London" que sur les plages de la Côte d'Azur. Son apparition dans le film On ne vit que deux fois aux côtés de James Bond et dans la série Le Prisonnier l'a définitivement fait entrer dans la légende et c'est un modèle aujourd'hui particulièrement convoité.

Au début des années 1980, la production été transférée dans une usine British Leyland installée au Portugal et c'est de là qu'est sortie la Mini Moke que nous proposons, achetée en 2020 à un professionnel de Sainte-Maxime, dans le Var. D’ailleurs, les 3 premiers caractères du numéro de châssis indiqués sur la carte grise reprennent le code de l’usine anglaise alors que la plaque constructeur ceux de l’usine portugaise. Sa propriétaire, qui dispose d'une résidence à Saint-Tropez, n'a parcouru depuis que quelques dizaines de kilomètres entre la place des Lices, sa maison et la plage des Canoubiers. En 2023, le garage spécialisé BJ Restaure de Bormes a effectué d'importants travaux mécaniques avec révision du moteur, des freins et pose de pneus neufs pour un total de 6 000 €. Depuis, la voiture n'a couvert qu'une trentaine de km et le compteur affiche 57 670 km. Avec sa carte grise deux places et sa mécanique éprouvée, cette voiture est en bel état, et est équipée de sa capote et de ses protections latérales complètes. Voiture de plage, de balade ou de ville, ludique et agile, cette Moke sera à l'aise dans toutes les situations !

 

Merci de noter que la voiture est vendue sans contrôle technique.







French title

Chassis no. SAXXKFP328S680770

 

- An extremely original and fun car

- Highly satisfactory condition

- €6,000 mechanical overhaul in 2023

- No reserve



A symbol of the 1960s and 1970s, the Moke designed by BMC on the basis of a Mini was not retained by the British army for whom it was intended, and became a fashionable car both in swinging London and on the beaches of the Côte d'Azur. Its appearance in the film You Only Live Twice alongside James Bond and in the series The Prisoner definitely made the car a legend, and it is a particularly coveted model today.

In the early 1980s, production was transferred to a British Leyland factory in Portugal, and that's where the Mini Moke we're offering came from, purchased in 2020 from a professional in Sainte-Maxime, in the Var. And actually, the first 3 digits of the VIN number on the French title use the English factory code while the manufacturer's plate uses the Portuguese factory one. Its owner, who has a residence in Saint-Tropez, has only travelled a few dozen kilometres between the Place des Lices, her home, and the Plage des Canoubiers beach. In 2023, BJ Restaure, a specialist garage in Bormes, carried out major mechanical work, including overhauling the engine and brakes and fitting new tyres, at a total cost of €6,000. Since then, the car has covered just 30 km, with the odometer now showing 57,670 km. With its two-seater registration and tried-and-tested mechanics, this car is in beautiful condition, and comes complete with its soft top and full side protection. A fun, agile car for the beach, for leisure driving, or for in the city, this Moke is at home in any situation!



Please note that the car is sold without technical inspection.

Un article de 2013 dans Land Rover Classic mettait à l’honneur ce bel exemplaire, lors d’un essai par l’acteur et réalisateur anglais Dominic Brunt. On y apprend que ce châssis long venait de bénéficier d’une remise en état chez le spécialiste renommé Simmonites, incluant une conversion en conduite à gauche en vue de l’exporter. Il fut d’ailleurs acheté l’année suivante par un important collectionneur français avant que son actuel propriétaire n’en fasse l’acquisition en 2022. Dans l’emblématique livrée « Light Green » rehaussé du fameux « toit tropical » pour réduire la condensation, cet exemplaire est équipé d’un moteur 4 cylindres essence de série III. Entre 2020 et 2022, il a bénéficié de travaux tels que le changement de la pompe à eau, le remplacement des pneumatiques, ou encore la reprise en peinture de certains éléments de carrosserie. Depuis, il a bénéficié d’un entretien courant et est en bon état d’usage. Avec ses deux longues banquettes parallèles à la route, qui viennent compléter les 6 places avant, ce tout-terrain iconique équipé d’un attelage vous emmènera nombreux à l’aventure hors des sentiers battus.



Merci de noter que l'embrayage sera refait à l'issue de la vente au frais du vendeur.

A 2013 article in Land Rover Classic featured this fine example, when it was tested by English actor and director Dominic Brunt. The article relates how this long wheelbase version had just been refurbished by renowned specialists Simmonites, including left-hand drive conversion for export. It was indeed purchased the following year by a major French collector, before its current owner acquired it in 2022. With the body painted the emblematic “Light Green”, and its famous “tropical roof” to reduce condensation, this model is powered by a Series III 4-cylinder petrol engine. Between 2020 and 2022, it underwent work to replace the water pump, fit new tyres and repaint some body parts. It has since been routinely serviced and is in good working order. With its two long inward facing bench seats, adding to the 6 front seats, this iconic off-roader (fitted with a tow bar) will take several of you off the beaten track. 



Please note that the clutch will be replaced after the auction at the seller's cost.

Carte grise française
Châssis n° 113.042.12.014955


- Superbe combinaison de couleurs

- Equipée de son hard-top

- Restauration de qualité

- Utilisation facile en boîte automatique



La 'Pagode', surnommée ainsi pour la forme de son toit rappelant l'architecture japonaise, fait partie de la grande lignée des SL chez Mercedes et prend la suite de la 190 SL. Déclinée dans trois motorisations, le modèle que nous présentons est équipé du 6 cylindres 2,3L très robuste et demandant un entretien limité. Ce 230 SL a été complètement restauré en carrosserie comme en cosmétique intérieure par le propriétaire précédent. Le dossier des travaux est important et montre un travail sérieux sans parler de la voiture elle-même qui se trouve dans un superbe état de présentation à tous les niveaux. Son intérieur bleu marine, avec la troisième place à l’arrière, est en accord avec la couleur de la capote. L’intérieur est superbe et ses moquettes grises sont de grande qualité. Elle possède son manuel d’origine. Son propriétaire actuel la possède depuis 2020 et l’entretient dans un garage spécialisé de Sainte-Maxime. Elle est équipée de son hard-top, au même niveau d’exigence que la voiture elle-même. Cette 230 SL, équipée d’une boîte automatique, vous offrira le confort et une facilité d’utilisation bien agréable et sera l'occasion pour vous d'accéder à cette lignée légendaire des cabriolets robustes et performants de la firme à l'Etoile, parfaite pour les routes ensoleillées de l’été.







French title

Chassis No 113.042.12.014955

 

- Stunning colour combination

- Equipped with its hard top

- Quality restoration

- Easy to drive with automatic gearbox

 

Nicknamed the “Pagoda” due to the distinctive shape of its roof, reminiscent of Japanese architecture, this model is part of the great SL lineage at Mercedes and succeeded the 190 SL. Available with three engine types, this particular example is powered by the very robust 2.3L 6-cylinder engine, which does not require regular servicing. Including the bodywork and interior cosmetics, this 230 SL was fully restored by the previous owner.

The extensive file accompanying the car shows the quality and seriousness of the work carried out, not to mention the car itself which is in superb condition throughout. Its navy-blue interior, which includes the third seat at the back, matches the colour of the hard top. The interior is stunning and its grey carpets are of high quality. It also includes its original manual. Its current owner has owned it since 2020 and has serviced it at a specialised garage in Sainte-Maxime. It is equipped with its hard top, with the same high standards as the car itself.

Fitted with an automatic transmission, this 230 SL is comfortable and pleasantly easy to drive; it will be an ideal opportunity for you to access this legendary lineage of robust and high-performance convertible cars from the brand with the star, ready to be enjoyed on sunny summer roads.



Photos © Loïc Kernen

Titre de circulation allemand
Châssis n° AR2467516


- 2ème main, même propriétaire depuis 35 ans

- Rare teinte “Giallo Prototipo” d’origine

- Importante remise en état en 2000

- Sans réserve



Cet élégant Spider Veloce appartient à la deuxième série et est équipé de la motorisation la plus puissante disponible à l’époque, le brillant double arbre à cames en tête de 2L et plus de 130cv. Outre ces qualités mécaniques, l’exemplaire présenté a été vendu neuf puis immatriculé en janvier 1978 en Allemagne dans une seyante et rare teinte « Giallo Prototipo », et c’est en 1990 que l’actuel propriétaire en a fait l’acquisition auprès du premier alors qu’il affichait environ 40 000 km. Dix ans plus tard, la voiture a bénéficié d’une importante remise en état de sa carrosserie avec remplacement des parties corrodées et traitement des corps creux avant d’être repeinte dans sa teinte d’origine. La sellerie en skaï noir a été refaite en cuir, incluant les panneaux de portes. Le beau cabriolet a ensuite été régulièrement utilisé et suivi : en 2023, un allumage électronique a été installé, et en 2024, la capote a été refaite, ainsi que divers détails de l’habitacle. Tous les fluides ont été remplacés l’an passé et le beau cabriolet affiche aujourd’hui un peu moins de 54 500 km. Prêt à prendre la route cet été, ce Spider Veloce n'a pas fini de faire tourner les têtes sur son passage.







German title

Chassis no. AR2467516



- 2nd hand, same owner for 35 years

- Rare original “Giallo Prototipo” colour

- Extensive overhaul in 2000

- No reserve

 

This elegant Spider Veloce belongs to the second series and is fitted with the most powerful engine available at the time, the brilliant 2L double overhead camshaft developing over 130hp. In addition to its mechanical qualities, the car presented here was sold new and then registered in Germany in January 1978, in a rare and attractive “Giallo Prototipo” colour, and the current owner acquired it from the first in 1990 with around 40,000 km on the clock. Ten years later, the car underwent major bodywork, with corroded parts replaced and hollow bodies treated, before being repainted in its original colour. The black leatherette upholstery was replaced with leather, including the door panels. This beautiful cabriolet was regularly used and maintained: in 2023, electronic ignition was installed, and in 2024, the soft top was replaced, along with various interior details. All the fluids were replaced last year, and this lovely car now has just under 54,500 km on the clock. Ready to hit the road this summer, this Spider Veloce is sure to turn heads.



Photos © Peter Singhof

Description:
Carte grise française
Châssis n° B5087237


- Remise en état et préparation complète en 2021

- Remorque aménagée quasi unique !

- 30 000 km depuis 2021, véhicule fiable



Cet exceptionnel Combi est à l’origine un modèle 231, modifié en désirable version 23 fenêtres. Acheté par un passionné du modèle, il a été intégralement restauré, aménagé et équipé entre mars et juillet 2021, en vue de nombreux road trips lointains. Un moteur neuf de 2020 cm3 et 120cv de chez Speed Shop a été installé, accolé à une boîte de vitesses à trompettes réétagée par un spécialiste du domaine. Pour la sécurité, des freins à disques ont été installés, un boîtier de direction à roulement monté pour réduire les jeux et augmenter le rayon de braquage et des amortisseurs Bilstein à l’arrière et Koni réglable à l’avant sélectionnés. A bord, l’habitacle a été isolé et équipé de tous les équipements de confort permettant l’autonomie dont une liste pourra être fournie sur demande. Un double système électrique a été installé, et comporte un module de branchement pour panneaux solaires, tandis que tout l’éclairage est confié à des LED. Un double branchement USB-A est dissimulé dans le cendrier et nous avons noté un convertisseur 12-220w pour brancher les PC portables. La sellerie a été réalisée sur mesure par un compagnon du devoir, avec mousse à mémoire de forme Bultex et habillage en skaï et Alcantara. Les sièges avant proviennent d’une Renault 5 Turbo, repensés pour être en adéquation avec le design. Le véhicule est, en outre, équipé d’un système de chauffage stationnaire Propex 2000W. Mais l’originalité de ce véhicule ne s’arrête pas là puisqu’il est accompagné d’une remorque fabriquée à partir d’un autre combi dont on ne connaîtrait que deux exemplaires au monde (les autres étant en fibre). Cette dernière accueille une plancha sur rails coulissants, une 2ème bouteille de gaz et tout l’équipement de camping pour libérer l’espace de l’habitacle. Depuis sa réalisation, ce T1 surnommé « Charly » a parcouru 30 000 km sans encombre, a fait les honneurs de la presse spécialisée et de rassemblements. Amateur exigeant, son propriétaire vient de lui faire bénéficier d’une peinture neuve complète. Il est évident que les voyageurs au long cours vont tomber sous le charme de cet engin unique préparé avec passion, connaissance et sans limite de coût !







French title

Chassis no. B5087237



- Completely overhauled and prepared in 2021

- Almost unique fitted trailer!

- 30,000 km since 2021, reliable vehicle

 

This exceptional Combi was originally a model 231, which was converted into the sought-after 23-window version. Bought by a fan, it was fully restored, fitted out and equipped between March and July 2021, with a view to numerous long road trips. A new 2020 cm3, 120hp Speed Shop engine was fitted, alongside a trumpet gearbox re-tuned by a specialist in the field. For safety, disc brakes were fitted, a bearing steering gear was mounted to reduce play and increase the turning radius, and Bilstein shock absorbers at the rear and adjustable Koni shock absorbers at the front were fitted. Inside, the cabin has been insulated and fitted out with all the comforts required for independent living, a list of which can be supplied on request. A dual electrical system has been installed, including a connection module for solar panels, with all lighting provided by LEDs. There is a double USB-A connection concealed in the ashtray, and we noted a 12-220w converter for connecting laptops. The upholstery was custom-made by a craftsman, with Bultex memory foam and leatherette and Alcantara trim. The front seats come from a Renault 5 Turbo, reworked to match the design. The van is also equipped with a Propex 2000W stationary heating system. But that’s not all, as this model comes with a trailer converted from another combi, of which only two are known to exist in the world (the others were made of fibreglass). This one has a plancha on sliding rails, a 2nd gas cylinder and all the camping equipment to free up cabin space. Since it was built, this T1, nicknamed “Charly”, has done 30,000 km without a hitch, and has appeared in the specialist press and various gatherings. Its owner, a demanding enthusiast, has just given it a completely new paint job. It goes without saying that long-distance travellers will be spellbound by this unique van, prepared with passion, knowledge and unlimited cost!



Photos © Paul Langlard

Description:
Description complète
Carte grise française
Châssis n° AS8001006073


- Entretien méticuleux

- Petit cabriolet mythique

- Agile, ludique et si désirable en cabriolet

- Sans réserve



En 1963, Honda, constructeur confirmé de motos performantes, aborda la construction automobile en proposant un coupé et un cabriolet de dimension minimale propulsés par un moteur à quatre cylindres en ligne de 530 cm3, emprunté à la gamme motos. À la S500 à transmission par chaînes succédèrent la S600 en 1964, puis en 1966 la S800 dont le moteur porté à 791 cm3 délivrait la belle puissance de 70 ch à plus de 8 000 tr/min, régime inédit pour une routière dans les années 1960. Sur cette dernière, un pont arrière classique remplaçait les chaînes. Dotée d'un tempérament essentiellement sportif et d'un comportement dynamique sain, cette petite bombe unique en son genre marqua son époque, tant en coupé qu'en cabriolet.

L’actuel propriétaire de cette superbe S800 l’a acquise lors du Salon Epoquauto à Lyon en tombant littéralement sous le charme de cette petite japonaise. Ce galeriste et spécialiste reconnu de la peinture flamande et hollandaise du XVe au XVIIe siècle, passionné d’automobiles et collectionneur de Lamborghini, voulait un petit cabriolet pour en profiter l’été dans les rues de Paris. Il vente avec passion « la vivacité et le côté ludique de ce petit bolide, si amusant à conduire avec ce moteur de moto qui monte dans les tours dans une sonorité ennivrante ! »

La circulation parisienne devenant trop compliquée, il décide de s’en séparer à contre-cœur « pour qu’un autre amateur puisse en profiter sur les routes tropéziennes » nous a-t-il confié.

Depuis six ans qu’il la possède, la voiture est entretenue chez Toni Auto à côté de Paris, mécanicien émérite aussi à l’aise pour entretenir les Lamborghini les plus prestigieuses que cette petite S800 si charmante. De couleur rouge, intérieur noir, elle se trouve donc en très bon état et mérite vivement de trouver un(e) nouveau(elle) passionné(e) qui la fera rouler sur des routes dégagées et si possible sinueuses et ensoleillées !



Merci de noter que ce véhicule est retiré.







French title

Chassis No AS8001006073



- Meticulously serviced

- Iconic small cabriolet

- Agile, playful and so desirable as a convertible

 

In 1963 and as a proven manufacturer of high-performance motorcycles, Honda entered the automobile industry by offering a coupe and a convertible of minimal dimensions powered by a 530 cc inline four-cylinder engine derived from its motorcycle range.

The chain-driven S500 was succeeded by the S600 in 1964 and then by the S800 in 1966. The engine of the latter was increased to 791 cc and delivered an impressive 70 hp at over 8,000 rpm, rev range unheard-of for a road car in the 1960s. This time, a conventional rear axle replaced the chains. With its fundamentally sporty character and dynamic handling, this unique little bombshell left a lasting mark on its era, both as a coupe and a convertible.

 

The current owner of this superb S800 acquired it at the Epoquauto Show in Lyon, after literally falling in love with this little Japanese car. This gallery owner and renowned specialist in Flemish and Dutch painting (between 15th and 17th centuries), as well as a car enthusiast and Lamborghini collector, wanted a small convertible to drive in the streets of Paris in the summer. He enthusiastically praises: “the liveliness and playfulness of this little car, so fun to drive with its motorcycle engine revving and its exhilarating sound!”

As the traffic in Paris became too problematic, he reluctantly decided to part with it “so that another enthusiast can enjoy it on the roads of Saint-Tropez”, he told us.

During his six years of ownership, the car was serviced by Toni Auto near Paris, a highly skilled mechanic equally adept at servicing the most prestigious Lamborghini models as he is with this charming little S800. Finished in red with a black interior, it is in very good condition and definitely deserves to find a new owner who will enjoy driving it on open roads and preferably, on winding and sunny ones!



Please note that contrary to what is indicated in the catalogue, the model of the car is S800. The French title is under process and will be provided to the buyer as soon as possible.



Please note that this lot has been withdrawn

 

Photos © Nino Hamet

- Vendue neuve en France

- Peinture complète de qualité en 2018

- Rare teinte rouge calypso et boîte manuelle

- Sans réserve



Un V12 5L de 300 cv, chef d'œuvre de mécanique, une ligne unique due à Klaus Kapitza et un haut niveau de technicité : voilà ce que proposait la 850i lors de sa sortie en 1989, se hissant immédiatement au rang de référence sur le segment des grands coupés sportifs. L’exemplaire présenté a été vendu neuf le 27 septembre 1991 par le concessionnaire BMW d’Evreux, ainsi que le confirme son carnet d’entretien tamponné par le même concessionnaire jusqu’en 2016, à 152 656 km. D’une rare et désirable teinte « Rouge Calypso » associé à un superbe intérieur en cuir noir, elle dispose de la boîte manuelle à 6 rapports recherchée par les connaisseurs. Son actuel propriétaire a pu en faire l’acquisition en 2017, et l’année suivante, la voiture a bénéficié d’une peinture complète dans sa teinte d’origine à la réputée carrosserie Gérard Jourdan de Menton. En 2021, à 158 320 km, la voiture a bénéficié d’une révision et n’a que peu roulé depuis puisqu’elle totalise un peu moins de 159 000 km ; des pneumatiques neufs seront fournis avec la voiture, à monter. Conservé avec soin, ce vaisseau amiral de la gamme BMW affiche un état de présentation rare tant à l’extérieur qu’à l’intérieur, et avec ses spécifications recherchées, il comblera les amateurs du modèle et les amateurs de voyages confortables à vitesses élevées.



Merci de noter que la carte grise est en cours d'obtention et sera fournie à l'acheteur dans les meilleurs délais. Suite à une erreur administrative, le numéro de série indiqué sur la précédente carte grise est WBABG11040CB13809 au lieu de WBAEG11040CB13809. 







French title

Chassis no. WBAEG11040CB13809



- Sold new in France

- Complete quality paintwork restoration in 2018

- Rare Calypso Red colour and manual gearbox

- No reserve

 

A mechanical masterpiece, the 5L V12 engine producing 300 hp, a unique design by Klaus Kapitza and a high level of technicality: this is what the 850i offered when it was launched in 1989, immediately becoming a reference within the large sports coupe segment.

This example was sold new on 27 September 1991 by the BMW dealership in Evreux, as confirmed by its service book, stamped by the same dealer until 2016, with 152,656 km on the clock. In a rare and desirable 'Calypso Red' colour, combined with a superb black leather interior, it features the 6-speed manual gearbox sought after by connoisseurs. Its current owner was able to acquire it in 2017, and the following year the car benefitted from a full repaint in its original colour at the renowned Gérard Jourdan body shop in Menton. In 2021, at 158,320 km, the car was serviced and has been driven very little since then, totalling just under 159,000 km. New tyres will be provided with the car, to be fitted. Carefully preserved, this flagship model of the BMW range boasts a rare condition both inside and out, and with its sought-after specification, it will delight fans of the model and lovers of comfortable travel at high speeds.



Please note that the French title is under process and will be provided to the buyer as soon as possible. The VIN number shown on the previous French title is WBABG11040CB13809 instead of WBAEG11040CB13809.

Titre de circulation italien
Châssis n° ZFA126A0003135633


- Rare cabriolet Pop

- Excellent état d'origine

- Ludique et agile

- Sans réserve

 

Remplaçante de la célébrissime Fiat 500, la Fiat 126 en reprenait le petit gabarit sous une robe plus moderne qui lui a assuré le succès avec plusieurs millions d'exemplaires produits de 1972 à 2000. En plus de l'Italie, la majeure partie de la production a été réalisée en Pologne par la société FSM et c'est sur cette base qu'a été conçue une version cabriolet quatre places, par la société Pop. En partant de la version fermée, la réalisation était très soignée, avec des portes échancrées et une vraie capote tendue sur des arceaux et comportant trois plexis assurant la visibilité. Des panneaux latéraux transparents apportaient un complément de protection et Pop en aurait fabriqué quelques centaines d'exemplaires.

 

C'est un de ces cabriolets que nous présentons, en excellent état d'origine affichant 19 000 km. Il s'agit d'une 126 Bis, donc équipée du moteur 700 cm3 de 26 ch à refroidissement liquide. Cette voiture présente l'attrait de la rareté et de l'originalité et, dans son état exemplaire, elle ne manquera pas de se distinguer des autres usagers et d'apporter à ses occupants le plaisir de sa carrosserie ouverte et de son comportement ludique.

 





 Italian title

Chassis no. ZFA126A0003135633



- Rare Pop Cabriolet

- Excellent original condition

- Fun and agile

- No reserve

 

Replacing the famous Fiat 500, the Fiat 126 took its small size and gave it a more modern look, ensuring its success with several million units produced between 1972 and 2000. In addition to Italy, most of the production was realised in Poland by the FSM company, and it was on this basis that a four-seater cabriolet version was designed by the Pop company. Starting with the solid top version, the design was very meticulous, with notched doors and an authentic soft top stretched over hoops and featuring three plexiglass panels to ensure visibility. Transparent side panels provided additional protection, and Pop is said to have produced several hundred examples.

 

Here we are presenting one of these cabriolet models, in excellent original condition and with 19,000 km on the clock. This is a 126 Bis, equipped with a 700 cc, 26 bhp, liquid-cooled engine. It's a rare and original car and, in its exemplary condition, it's sure to stand out from the crowd, treating passengers to the pleasure of its open body and playful handling.

Description:
Titre de circulation allemand
Châssis n° 305422 Moteur n° 909160


- Matching numbers, couleur, et sellerie

- Etat de préservation rare

- Une des toutes premières versions de la 911

- Sans réserve



Comme nous l’apprend un certificat délivré par Porsche, cette 911 fut livrée neuve le 10 août 1966 à Porsche of America, à Teaneck dans les faubourgs de New York, elle était de couleur "Polo Rot" (code 6602) avec intérieur en "Kunstleder" (simili cuir). Elle a été ensuite vendue à son premier propriétaire, un certain Richard Noble, qui l'a immatriculée en 1967 et utilisée quelques années avant de la céder à Norman Evenden, propriétaire d'un garage automobile situé à Horseheads, dans l'État de New York. Son fils Howard l'a ensuite exportée en Allemagne où elle a été restaurée dans sa teinte d'origine, le moteur et la boîte de vitesses faisant eux aussi l'objet de travaux de remise en état. Une fois refaite, cette Porsche 911 a été vendue à son actuel propriétaire en 2017 et, aujourd'hui, elle se présente dans un état attrayant, avec une peinture vive et un aménagement intérieur préservé d'origine. Elle est dotée de sa trousse à outils, d'un livret d'utilisation de l’autoradio et elle est équipée de sa mécanique 6-cylindres d'origine.

 

Cette voiture particulièrement intéressante, qui correspond à l'une des toutes premières séries de 911, est dotée de la première coque à empattement court, du tableau de bord à garniture en bois qui a ici été vernis, des deux carburateurs Weber triple corps qui ont remplacé en février 1966 les Solex initiaux et de l'inscription "911" horizontale sur le capot arrière au lieu du logo incliné. Dans cette configuration, elle n'a été produite que huit mois avant de laisser place à la 911 S.

Rare et recherchée, moins onéreuse que les modèles antérieurs, cette 911 bénéficie de la ligne pure du premier dessin et son poids limité permet une agilité et des sensations de conduite que ne connaissent pas les versions plus récentes. Dans son état enviable, elle constitue une rare occasion qui ne devrait pas laisser les passionnés indifférents.

 

 



German title

Chassis no. 305422

Engine no. 909160

 

- Matching numbers, colour and upholstery

- Rare condition

- One of the very first versions of the 911

- No reserve

 

As the certificate issued by Porsche states, this 911 was delivered new on 10th August 1966 to Porsche of America in Teaneck, New York, in “Polo Rot” (code 6602) with “Kunstleder” (leatherette) interior. It was sold to its first owner, a certain Richard Noble, who registered it in 1967 and used it for a few years before selling it to Norman Evenden, the owner of a car garage in Horseheads, New York. His son Howard then exported it to Germany, where it was restored to its original colour, and the engine and gearbox were also restored. Once restored, this Porsche 911 was sold to its current owner in 2017, is displayed today in beautiful condition, with bright paintwork and original preserved interior fittings. It comes with its tool kit, a user manual for the car radio, and its original 6-cylinder engine.

 

This particularly interesting car, one of the very first 911 series, features the first short-wheelbase body, the wood-trimmed dashboard which has been varnished, the two triple-barrel Weber carburettors which replaced the original Solex in February 1966, and the horizontal “911” lettering on the rear hood instead of the sloping logo. It was only produced in this configuration for eight months before being replaced by the 911 S.

Rare and sought-after, and less expensive than earlier models, this 911 has the pure lines of the first design, and its limited weight gives it the agility and drive not felt in more recent versions. In enviable condition, this car offers a rare opportunity that won’t leave fans indifferent.

Description:
Carte grise française
Châssis n° VF1C4050500958975


- Dans la même famille depuis 1992

- Deuxième main, à peine 57 200 km

- Etat d'origine rare et intérieur bien préservé

Cette voiture est étonnante par son histoire et son état : il s'agit d'une deuxième main, dans la même famille depuis 1992, remarquablement préservée d'origine. Achetée neuve par un M. Demichel, de Ruynes-en-Margeride (Cantal), elle a été vendue le 21 avril 1992 (à 36 274 km), par l'intermédiaire du garage de la Margeride, au père de l'actuel propriétaire. Il a fait à cette occasion installer un système d'alarme Sodicam et, comme il bénéficiait d'une voiture de fonction dans le cadre de son activité au conseil régional de Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur, il a très peu utilisé cette Renault 5 GT Turbo.

Le 14 mars 2023, dans le cadre de sa succession, elle est passée entre les mains de son fils. Depuis, celui-ci l'a fait complètement réviser avec notamment vidange et vérification du circuit de refroidissement.

Grâce à ce passé particulier, cette Renault 5 GT Turbo est dans un état d'origine rare. Certains éléments de carrosserie semblent avoir été repeints comme le capot mais d'autres comme le pavillon paraissent en peinture d'origine, légèrement passée. L'intérieur est entièrement d'origine, à peine usé ce qui est rare sur ce modèle. Affichant aujourd'hui 57 200 km d'origine, cette voiture est accompagnée de documents confirmant son histoire, tel que la copie de la première carte grise, la facture d’achat de 1992 ainsi que le manuel d’utilisation. Il est rare de rencontrer dans un tel état une Renault 5 GT Turbo qui, capable de 200 km/h, était une des "petites bombes" les plus performantes de son époque et procurait les sensations uniques de son moteur turbocompressé.



 

French title

Chassis no. VF1C4050500958975

 

- In the same family since 1992

- Second hand, only 57,200 km

- Rare original condition and well-preserved interior

- Documented history

 - No reserve

 

This is an astonishing car for its history and condition: second-hand, in the same family since 1992, and remarkably well preserved from the start. It was bought new by a Mr. Demichel of Ruynes-en-Margeride (Cantal), and sold on 21st April 1992 (with 36,274 km), through the garage de la Margeride, to the current owner's father. On this occasion, he had a Sodicam alarm system installed and, as he had a company car as part of his job at the Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur regional council, he seldom drove this Renault 5 GT Turbo.

On 14th March 2023, as part of his estate, it passed into the hands of his son. He had it completely overhauled, including draining and checking the cooling system.

Thanks to this wonderful story, this Renault 5 GT Turbo is in rare original condition. Some body parts, such as the bonnet, appear to have been repainted, while others, such as the roof panel, seem to have their original, slightly faded paintwork. The interior is entirely original, with only minor wear, which is rare for this model. With its original 57,200 km, this car comes with documents confirming its history, including a copy of the first registration document, the 1992 purchase invoice and the owner's manual. It's rare to come across a Renault 5 GT Turbo in such great condition. Capable of 200 kph, it was one of the most powerful “pocket rockets” of its time, delivering the unique sensations of its turbocharged engine.

- 1ère main, vendue neuve à Monaco

- Version à carrosserie en acier galvanisé

- Suivi depuis l’origine, importants travaux récents

En 1968, la production de la Mini Moke fût transférée en Australie. Elle fût d’abord distribuée sous le nom de Morris Mini Moke puis Leyland Moke à partir de 1973. Plus tard, en 1977, une nouvelle série « Californian » visant à rafraîchir l’image du modèle fut présentée. Ainsi qu’en témoigne sa facture d’achat d’origine, cet exemplaire a été acheté neuf par son actuel propriétaire chez British Motors à Monte-Carlo le 13 juillet 1981. Blanche à l’origine, cette Moke a depuis été régulièrement utilisée et entretenue, ainsi qu’en témoigne un important dossier de suivi. Entre 2021 et 2023, elle a bénéficié d’importants travaux : train avant remis en état, les étriers de freins remplacés, la carrosserie intégralement repeinte. La sellerie et la capote ont également été restaurées. En décembre 2024, le moteur 998 cm3 a été remplacé par un neuf, 2600 km ont été parcourus depuis. Disposant de 4 places, y compris sur la carte grise, cette charmante Moke est également équipée d’un attelage et présente un avantage de taille : s’agissant des dernières versions « Californian », elle dispose d’une carrosserie en acier galvanisé qui vous fera oublier les problèmes de corrosion des autres versions. Avec de nombreux travaux récents, une expertise de 2022, un historique exceptionnel et son allure de baroudeuse, cette Moke vous comblera chaque été !







Monaco title

Chassis No 100959



 

- One owner from new, sold new in Monaco

- Version with galvanised steel bodywork

- Regularly serviced since new, major recent work

- No reserve



In 1968, the production of the Mini Moke was transferred to Australia. It was first distributed under the Morris Mini Moke name, then Leyland Moke in 1973. Later in 1977, a new “Californian” series was introduced to refresh the model’s image. As evidenced by its original invoice, this particular example was purchased new by its current owner from British Motors in Monte Carlo on the 13th July 1981. Originally white, this Moke was regularly used and serviced, as evidenced by a substantial servicing file. Between 2021 and 2023, it had some major work done: the front axle restored, all brake callipers replaced and the bodywork fully repainted. The upholstery and soft top were also restored. In December 2024, the 998cc engine was replaced by a new one, and 2600 km have been covered since then. With 4 seats included, even on its title, this charming Moke is also equipped with a towing bar and has a major advantage: being one of the latest “Californian” versions, it has a galvanised steel bodywork which will make you forget about corrosion issues on other versions. With numerous recent works, an expertise from 2022, an exceptional history and its adventurous look, this Moke will fill you with happiness every summer!



Photos © Loïc Kernen

Porsche introduced the 911 SC “Super Carrera” for the 1978 model year, consolidating the previous 911 and Carrera lines into one. Built around the fully galvanized G-series chassis that debuted two years prior, the SC adopted a new 3.0-liter engine based on the flat-six in the type-930 911 Turbo. Robust and reliable, it featured a stiffer die-cast aluminum crankcase and Bosch K Jetronic electronic fuel injection in place of the magnesium crankcase and mechanical fuel injection of the outgoing 2.7-liter engine. Although peak power decreased slightly compared to the 2.7-liter, the new 3.0-liter flat-six’s wider power band and improved torque were a boon for everyday driving.

The 911 SC launched in Coupe and Targa body styles. With more than 60,000 cars constructed over its six-year lifespan, the 911 SC was a huge success right from the start.

This well-documented, “slick-top,” North American-market example will be of great interest to Porsche collectors, having remained within the same family since new and been driven only 13,228 miles as of cataloguing time. It was delivered to Stuttgart on 15 March 1982 through Porsche’s European Delivery Program for its Philadelphia-based owner. The German plate used during this trip through Europe accompanies the car to this day, as does the original tourist shipping order invoice. Per this document, the car retains its original color scheme of Black over Black Leather and factory options, which include a black roof liner, cruise control, alarm system, tinted glass, and US-spec catalyst.

This collector-grade 911 SC remained in the Northeast until the original owner relocated it to Florida in the late 2000s. The vehicle was moved to Colorado in 2021 by the original owner’s daughter, where it benefitted from regular service. This Porsche 911 SC was cherished from day one, as evidenced by the extremely low mileage and meticulous records, which include full service and maintenance documentation since delivery from Germany and even the original check written to purchase the car on 4 March 1982. A receipt for U.S. Customs duties and copies of the manufacturer’s statement of origin, shipping invoice, and temporary German registration for the tourist delivery program are also included in the accompanying history file.

Being a “slick-top” with no sunroof only adds to the car’s abundant appeal for Porsche purists. This, together with its many other virtues, puts the 911 SC Coupe offered here among the very best of its type to come to market. In addition to its history file and German tourist-delivery plate, the car is accompanied by tools, a Porsche rear service cover, a first aid kit, an air compressor, factory manuals, and the original warranty and maintenance book stamped with the car’s delivery date of 19 March 1982 to Porsche headquarters in Stuttgart.

Following a dramatic redesign in 1968, the Plymouth GTX adopted the sleek, coke-bottle silhouette that became emblematic of Chrysler’s muscle car era. For those with an appetite for unmatched performance, a $604 upgrade unlocked the legendary 426-cubic-inch Hemi V-8—an engineering marvel capable of outpacing nearly every street machine of its time. Though few customers opted for this costly addition, Hemi-equipped GTXs have since ascended to near-mythic status, now considered among the most sought-after American automobiles ever built.

Completed on 14 November 1968 at Plymouth’s St. Louis, Missouri assembly plant, this authentic “J-Code” 1969 Plymouth GTX Hemi is a highly optioned example of the automaker’s finest era and ranks among the most well-preserved Hemi Mopars in existence. Finished in what is believed to be its factory-applied Code F8 Ivy Green Metallic paint over black vinyl trim, the car’s fender tag checks all the options boxes that muscle car collectors crave, including the 426-cubic-inch Hemi V-8, four-speed gearbox, Track Pak Dana 60 rear axle with 3.54:1 Sure Grip differential, Air Grabber cold-air induction hood, 26-inch high-capacity radiator, and bucket seats. Other notable options include a Music Master AM radio, variable-speed wipers, drip rail and body-side brightwork, and a white longitudinal stripe.

Rumored to have been ordered new by a soldier serving in Vietnam, the car is said to have been collected upon his return and immediately pressed into service on the drag strip—most notably at Great Lakes Dragway in Union Grove, Wisconsin, where it reportedly posted a best quarter-mile time of 11.01 seconds. Said to have been used almost exclusively for drag racing and never driven in bad weather, the car accumulated many of the 9,675 miles showing on the odometer one quarter mile at a time.

Eventually, engine and transmission issues forced it into early retirement, and it was stored in the original owner's heated warehouse, where it remained untouched for years. In the mid-1990s, an enthusiast acquired the car and commissioned a complete overhaul of its original, numbers-matching 426-cubic-inch Hemi V-8 engine and four-speed transmission while maintaining the car’s stunning level of preservation.

Having passed through the hands of several discerning collectors since its revival, this GTX Hemi is offered with a bevy of period paperwork including its original broadcast sheet, dealer invoice, and bill of sale, as well as a Galen Govier report and an assortment of service invoices.

An outstanding example, this authentic Plymouth GTX Hemi captures the muscle car era at full throttle—a time where brute power and bold style converged to create one of the most iconic American performance machines ever built.

Completed in October 1991, this early-production 512 TR is a superb example of one of Ferrari's most celebrated modern classics. Finished in the quintessential Italian sports car livery of Rosso Corsa over beige leather, it perfectly captures the bold styling and spirited elegance that define Ferrari’s flat-12 supercars of the era.

An evolution of the iconic Testarossa, the Ferrari 512 TR offered dramatic styling paired with significant mechanical and performance refinements. Its 4.9-liter flat-12 engine produced 428 horsepower, propelling the car from 0 to 60 mph in less than 5.0 seconds on its way to a top speed exceeding 190 mph. Ferrari revamped the engine layout, five-speed manual gearbox, and suspension for improved balance, responsiveness, and drivability, while upgraded intake and exhaust systems enhanced both performance and the flat-12’s unmistakable soundtrack. Subtle refinements to the nose, rear deck, and integrated aerodynamic elements distinguish the 512 TR visually from its predecessor, while also improving airflow and cooling efficiency.

Sold new via Lake Forest Sports Cars (now Ferrari Lake Forest) in Illinois, this example’s low mileage—30,619 at cataloguing time—and accompanying service records indicate that it received caring upkeep throughout its life. In 2016, it joined a private family collection in the Pacific Northwest. Besides its maintenance records, a factory tool kit and manuals with a leather pouch are included in the sale.

With approximately 2,300 units produced from 1991 through 1994, the 512 TR remains far rarer than the original Testarossa, and is widely regarded as the most driver-focused and dynamically refined of the flat-12 Ferraris. Whether destined for spirited road use, concours display, or as part of a curated collection, this superb 512 TR offers a compelling opportunity to acquire a standout example of one of Ferrari's most prized contemporary icons.

Immortalized in Steve McQueen’s Bullitt, the Dodge Charger remains one of the most iconic American automobiles. With its aggressive full-width grille, hidden headlights, and signature flying-buttress roof pillars, the Charger exudes menace even standing still, while its sculpted profile, recessed tail panel, and upturned rear deck embody the boldest design cues of late-1960s Americana. In a remarkable convergence of design and performance, the Charger emerged alongside one of America’s greatest engines, the NASCAR-bred 426-cubic-inch Hemi V-8—a pairing that forged an enduring icon in muscle car legend.

Constructed in Michigan at Dodge’s Hamtramck Assembly Plant—known locally as “Dodge Main”—on 18 October 1968, this early production Dodge Charger R/T Hemi left the factory as it appears today, finished in code F8 Dark Green Metallic with a black vinyl roof and transverse R/T stripe over black vinyl trim. Boasting a mighty 426-cubic-inch V-8, the car was further specified with numerous go-fast options, including a four-speed manual transmission, Super Trak Pak Dana 60 rear axle with 4.10:1 Sure Grip differential, power front disc brakes, and high-capacity, 26-inch radiator. The factory four-speed makes it one of 207 Dodge Charger R/T Hemis equipped as such for 1969, this according to the National Hemi Owner’s Association. Obviously intended to look as good as it drove, the car was also equipped with bucket seats and a center console, as well as a light package, drip-rail and beltline brightwork, variable wipers, and a Music Master AM radio.

Sporting the hallmarks of a complete restoration to factory specifications and with numbers-matching engine and transmission present, the car is accompanied by its original broadcast sheet, 1969 Dodge Charger owner’s manual, warranty booklet, and history report from Mopar guru Galen Govier.

A pillar of American muscle car lore, this Dodge Charger R/T Hemi, well-documented and restored to factory specifications, represents an exceptional opportunity to acquire one of the most iconic and enduring designs in automotive history.

Introduced at the Geneva Motor Show in 1957, the 3500 GT marked a turning point for Maserati, cementing its reputation as a maker of refined and alluring grand tourers. Designed by Carrozzeria Touring of Milan, the 3500 GT Coupe seamlessly blended elegant Italian styling with the performance pedigree of Maserati’s championship-winning racers. Under the hood a 3.5-liter twin-cam straight-six, derived from the world-beating 350S racing engine, initially featured Weber carburetors and later mechanical fuel injection. Early models, such as the example offered here, are particularly prized for their carbureted configuration and pure lines.

Built on a lightweight tubular chassis and clothed in Superleggera aluminum coachwork, the 3500 GT offered effortless high-speed cruising with innovations like front disc brakes and a ZF five-speed manual gearbox. With approximately 2,200 coupes constructed from 1957 through 1964, the model is rare and highly collectible.

The 3500 GT offered here, chassis 1730, is reported to have been sold new in Italy in July 1961, finished as it is today in Lancia Blu Scuro over dark red leather—quite an attractive combination. An early production example, chassis 1730 possesses among the model’s most desirable features, including a trio of Weber carburetors, front disc brakes, and the ZF five-speed manual gearbox. The car is believed to have remained with its first owner until the mid-1980s when it is said to have passed to another conscientious Italian enthusiast. Badges affixed throughout the car indicate that it is registered with the International Maserati Register as number 002.

With its distinguished livery and irresistible patina, this car offers the discerning collector a coveted opportunity to acquire a well-preserved and immensely appealing example of one of Maserati’s most celebrated grand tourers.

The landmark 512 BB, or Berlinetta Boxer, shared the same flat-12 engine configuration as some of Ferrari’s most accomplished racing designs—notably, the contemporaneous 312B2 and 312B3 Formula One cars. It succeeded the 365 GT4 BB, which was the Italian automaker’s first-ever mid-engine, 12-cylinder production car. Both shared an innovative architecture that placed the engine atop a five-speed gearbox to minimize the wheelbase and maximize interior space. For the 512 BB, the 12-cylinder "boxer" engine—so-called for its horizontally opposed pistons—gained dry-sump lubrication and a longer stroke, which significantly improved drivability. Meanwhile, the car’s trendsetting Pininfarina styling evolved from the preceding 365 GT4 BB with subtle tweaks.

In 1981, the third and final iteration of the series debuted. Newly designated 512 BBi, it abandoned the four triple-barrel Weber carburetors and replaced them with cutting-edge Bosch K-Jetronic ignition—accounting for the “i” in the model name. This modification had a negligible effect on absolute performance, but mid-range torque increased by around 20 pounds-feet, rendering the 512 BBi yet more tractable than its carburetor-fed equivalent. The BBi was blessed with performance figures of 0–60 mph in 5.4 seconds and a top speed of 179 mph. Still impressive by today’s standards, it was otherworldly in the early-1980s.

This example, chassis 39927, is one of just 1,007 of the 512 BBi models constructed from 1981 through 1984. Said to have been originally delivered to France, it is believed to have been imported into the United States in 2019, though no documentation was available at cataloguing time to confirm those claims.

While the exterior is finished in familiar Rosso Corsa paintwork, the interior sports a truly special and believed to be uncommon Nero Stoffa interior with gray wool inserts, said to have been developed in conjunction with fashion house Zegna, renowned for producing luxurious wool fabrics. With 72,068 kilometers (44,781 miles) on the odometer as of cataloguing time, the Ferrari had its windshield wiper mechanism and motor, spark plugs, ignition wires, and distributor cap and rotor replaced in January 2023.

The ideal Ferrari for those with an appreciation of rarity and high fashion, this 512 BBi undoubtably checks both boxes.

The Series 2 Aston Martin Lagonda saloon launched at the 1976 London Motor Show, with deliveries beginning in 1979. Whereas the Series 1 variant was essentially a four-door DBS V8, the Series 2 was a clean-sheet design by William Towns, who employed the “folded paper” design language that was popular in the 1970s as seen on the DMC DeLorean, Lamborghini Countach, and Lotus Espirit. Only the dependable Tadek Marek 5.3-liter V-8 engine was carried over from Series 1 to Series 2 Lagondas. The interior was entirely new, featuring traditional swathes of soft leather juxtaposed with avant-garde and advanced instrumentation, providing a futuristic experience for both driver and passengers when compared to its competitors. With only 645 Lagondas produced from 1976 through 1989, according to Aston Martin, they remain rare.

This example sports a highly attractive maroon exterior over a tan leather interior with brown piping and beautiful burled wood inlays. It features a delightful period-correct NEC car phone and a replacement Continental head unit with USB connectivity. Accompanying paperwork includes a bill of sale, correspondence, notes, previous registrations, and a series of invoices dating back to 1993.

In 2018, the car received a major service with repairs to the suspension, brakes, engine, cooling, air conditioning, and exhaust. Showing just 22,437 miles at cataloguing time, this rare Aston Martin Lagonda is certain to turn heads and fast becoming a must-have for those seeking a unique addition to their collection.

Unveiled in 1970, the Corvette LT-1 holds a distinguished place in Corvette history as the Chevrolet’s first serious return to high-performance, small-displacement engineering since the end of its fuel-injected engines in 1965.

At the heart of the LT-1 was a 350-cubic-inch small-block V-8 rated at a formidable 370 horsepower. Developed for the Trans Am racing series. Equipped with a solid-lifter camshaft, 11.0:1 compression, and a Holley four-barrel carburetor, the LT-1 delivered raw, high-revving performance that rivaled many big-block contemporaries, yet offered a more balanced driving experience thanks to its lighter weight and improved handling dynamics. Visually, the LT-1 was a subtle alternative to its fire-breathing big-block counterparts, with no extravagant exterior cues beyond discreet badging and a purposeful stance.

According to its accompanying factory Protect-O-Plate warranty booklet, this authentic LT-1 Corvette Coupe was sold new to Mr. Michael Mantia on 28 May 1970 via Charlie’s Chevrolet of St. Louis, Missouri. Given the car’s wonderful level of preservation, Mr. Mantia evidently cherished his prized Corvette with the car now displaying just 24,234 miles at cataloguing time. Cloaked in its factory-correct livery of Marlboro Maroon over black vinyl upholstery, the car is also equipped with power brakes, steering, and AM/FM radio. Prior to consignor acquiring it, this LT-1 passed through the collection of baseball great Reggie Jackson, who, beyond his sporting legend, is a well-known connoisseur of fine muscle cars. Crucially, inspection of the stamping pad on the engine confirms the presence of the last nine digits of the chassis number on the block, indicating a numbers-matching LT-1 engine, further substantiated by a report on file from Classic Car Affirmation Services. Besides its coveted, factory Protect-O-Plate, the car is also accompanied by copies of its original dealer invoice, delivery checklist, and registration receipt, as well as a 1990 California title in Reggie Jackson’s name. Also included are a certificate and scoring sheet for a National Corvette Restorers Society Top Flight Award received at the St. Louis chapter show in April 2012.

For collectors seeking a Corvette that balances performance, collectability, and sheer driving enjoyment, the LT-1 Corvette remains a compelling and increasingly sought-after choice—a cornerstone model from the golden age of American muscle cars.

Ten years after the Countach forever altered the supercar landscape, Lamborghini set to work on its replacement. In April 1987, about halfway through the new supercar’s five-year development cycle, Chrysler acquired Lamborghini, keeping it solvent. The American automaker’s influence would extend well beyond Lamborghini’s balance sheet, with its own design studio reportedly tweaking Marcello Gandini’s original design for the Countach successor. Named the Diablo after a famously ferocious fighting bull, it debuted in 1990 to critical acclaim, praised for its clean, yet impactful shape and impressive performance, as well as its more accommodating interior, for which Chrysler was given much credit.

A mid-mounted, 48-valve variant of Lamborghini’s dual-overhead-cam 5.7-liter V-12 engine with computer-controlled multi-point fuel injection was good for 485 brake horsepower and 428 pounds-feet of torque—enough to elevate heart rates and catapult the rear-drive supercar to over 200 mph. The Diablo would carry Lamborghini into the new millennium, with production through 2001 encompassing many iterations, notably including the addition of all-wheel drive—now a Lamborghini mainstay—in 1993.

The impressive Diablo offered here won multiple best-in-class awards at concours and exotic car events throughout Florida from 2009 through 2016, while under previous ownership. Since being acquired by the present owner in 2017, it has been driven sparingly and continued to benefit from careful maintenance.

Finished in red over tan and showing less than 44,664 kilometers (27,753 miles) on the odometer as of cataloguing time, this pampered Diablo is ready impress its next caretaker along with countless admiring onlookers at future car shows.

Detroit-Electric stands out as by far one of the most successful and longest-surviving manufacturers of early electric automobiles, remaining in production from 1907 through 1939. As the petroleum industry’s infrastructure took over in the early 20th century and drove most steam and electric cars into oblivion, Detroit Electric somehow managed to carry on, producing simple but solidly built cars. The company’s best year, 1914, saw a production of 4,669 cars, putting it decidedly in a niche market compared to the likes of Ford. But the scrappy automaker persisted even as the fondness for electric cars—favored, particularly by women, for their quiet, exhaust-free operation and not needing to be hand cranked—began to wane after 1916, when most production automobiles offered electric starters.

Styling upgrades such as the addition of “false fronts” kept Detroit Electric’s offerings up with current trends and even an open speedster proved popular with buyers. Still, production dropped steadily, even after prices were reduced from a peak of $4,000 in 1921. Yet Detroit Electric persisted, offering buyers from 1930 onward the option of conventional bodies supplied by Dodge or Willys-Overland to sit atop their chassis. Remarkably, the firm soldiered on still offering the classic, though positively archaic, “parlor on wheels” body style with tiller steering through the end of production, which some believe persisted until as late as 1941.

One such example, a 1918 Model 75A Brougham, is offered here. Beautifully finished in burgundy and black over gray broadcloth with red carpeting, it benefits from a previous restoration that has been freshened within the past few years, according to the consignor. The cabin is simple, yet elegant and inviting, with minimal adornment and basic instrumentation to monitor speed and battery output. With the feeling of a lounge on wheels, the driver operates the car via a tiller while sitting on the main, rear bench seat. A swiveling front seat and rear/side-facing jump-seat up continue the salon-like feel. In preparation for the sale, new deep-cycle batteries were installed for improved performance.

As today’s major manufacturers increasingly commit to pure electric vehicles, those of a century ago warrant a fresh look from collectors and enthusiasts. This outstanding example with appealing looks and ease of ownership, is sure to charm the dedicated electric car enthusiast and newcomer alike.

Introduced in May 1957, the new XK 150 built on the popular XK 120 and XK 140 before it, marking the third and final evolution of the brilliant XK series from Jaguar. While continuing to use a shortened Mark V chassis and bearing a strong resemblance to its predecessors, the XK 150 was slightly wider and featured a higher beltline replacing the trendy cut-down doors of the XK 120 and XK 140. A wider front grille improved engine cooling and a single-piece curved windscreen improved forward visibility. At launch, the XK 150 was available in both Fixed Head and Drophead Coupe body styles, with the Open Two-Seater roadster following in March 1958.

A clear case of racing improving the breed, the XK 150 was Jaguar’s first road model equipped with Dunlop four-wheel disc brakes, which played a key role in the company’s second victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans with the C-Type in 1953. A 3.4-liter version of Jaguar’s already-legendary XK inline six-cylinder engine powered the XK 150 until late 1959. A more powerful 3.8-liter version was introduced toward the end of the model’s production and these rare variants are the most desirable to collectors. Jaguar produced a total of 7,929 XK 150 models from 1957 through 1960, and of those, only 586 were Drophead Coupes with the 3.8-liter engine, according to Jaguar: The History of a Great British Car by Andrew Whyte.

This original left-hand-drive XK 150 Drophead Coupe completed production on 26 February 1960 and was dispatched on 11 March 1960 via Jaguar Cars, New York to its first owner in America, a Mr. C. Wallace. Originally finished in Pearl Grey over Red trim with a Black soft-top, it is now finished in the lovely combination of silver over black leather with a black Haartz soft-top. Notably, the car does retain its original body and numbers-matching 3.8-liter engine with dual SU carburetors.

Although its earlier history is unknown, the car is understood to have been fully restored in 2006 and later acquired by West Coast collector Paul Petrovich that same year. He would retain the car for 15 years and have it fully repainted, much of the chrome renewed, and some mechanical refurbishment performed in 2018. That year, the car is said to have participated in the prestigious Pebble Beach Tour D’Elegance across the Monterey Peninsula and Big Sur, a testament to its fastidious upkeep.

Benefitting from a steady regimen of proper maintenance and mechanical sorting, this attractive XK 150 3.8-Litre Drophead Coupe is accompanied by a Jaguar Daimler Heritage Trust Production Record Trace Certificate and a selection of work orders and service receipts. With its balance of sharp handling, gutsy power, and vastly improved passenger comfort, the 150 is the driving enthusiast’s pick of the XK range. Featuring great colors and delivering immense character and presence, this sophisticated Jaguar is more than worthy of continued preservation and appreciation, just as it has enjoyed under prior ownership.

The Ferrari 365 GTC/4’s flowing wedge shape by Filippo Sapino of Pininfarina was a significant departure from the more traditional profile of its predecessors when it debuted at the 1971 Geneva Motor Show. Proportioned like a two-seater coupe while cleverly incorporating fold-down rear seats, the GTC/4 effectively replaced two models, the 365 GTC and 365 GT 2+2. Both in design and performance, the 365 GTC/4 was more subdued and luxurious than the aggressive two-seater 365 GTB/4 built on the same chassis. Ferrari produced approximately 500 examples over 18 months, the bulk of which were sold in the United States.

This 365 GTC/4, chassis 15883, completed manufacture in August 1972 and was dispatched to the United States for distribution through casino magnate William Harrah’s Ferrari dealership Modern Classic Motors in Reno, Nevada. Finished as it is today in Grigio Argento (2.443.048) over a unique Nero Cogolo (Panno 22) interior of black leather with attractive tartan cloth inserts, it came equipped from the factory with power windows, air conditioning, and a heated windscreen.

Following its arrival at Modern Classic Motors in Reno, 15883 was reportedly sent to Chic Vandagriff’s Hollywood Sport Cars in California where it found its first owner later that year. This fortunate caretaker cherished 15883 for nearly 30 years before parting with it in 2002. The car then passed through several owners before joining a notable private collection.

Believed to be highly original, it appears to retain much of its original paint and interior, including the appealing tartan cloth inserts. Work completed in April 2025 included refurbishing the braking system. Showing just 30,585 miles at cataloguing time, 15883 would make for a great touring companion or preservation-class entrant at concours. It is accompanied by a jacking kit and history report from Ferrari historian Marcel Massini.
